column2: Parkinson's disease is a degenerative disorder of the central nervous system.
Parkinson's disease treatments manage early symptoms only.
Parkinson's disease is diagnosed by exclusion and treatment efficacy.
Parkinson's disease symtoms include slowness of movements (bradykinesia) and rigidity, resting tremor, or postural instability.
Parkinson's disease treatments include Levodopa, Dopamine agonists, and MAO-B inhibitors.
The motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease result from the death of dopamine-generating cells in the substantia nigra, a region of the midbrain.
Drugs such as amantadine and anticholinergics may be useful as treatment of motor symptoms for Parkinson's disease.

Lifestyle changes may be helpful for Parkinson's disease, including good general nutrition and health, exercising, regular rest periods, avoiding stress, physical therapy, assistive devices, and social workers or other counseling.
